Topics include: Leadership Authority and Responsibility, Military Justice, and Airmen Comprehensive Assessment. Leadership Laboratory is mandatory for AFROTC cadets and complements this course.

description: $Detailed study of human body structures using a regional and systems approach. Emphasis is placed on structural relationships and the integration of body systems.

name: Laboratory in Human Anatomy
description: $A detailed hands-on study of human structure using high resolution models, specialized specimens and dissection of selected mammalian organs and tissues. $A detailed hands-on study of human structure using high resolution models, specialized specimens and dissection of selected mammalian organs and tissues.

name: Human Physiology
description: $Students will explore the function and adaptation of the human body emphasizing neuromuscular, cardio-respiratory, gastrointestinal, endocrine, and urinary systems to maintain homeostasis and human health. $Students will explore the function and adaptation of the human body emphasizing neuromuscular, cardio-respiratory, gastrointestinal, endocrine, and urinary systems to maintain homeostasis and human health.

name: Physiology Laboratory
description: $Course focuses on non-invasive human experiments supplemented with in vitro tissues experiments to explore fundamental physiological concepts and learn basic methods of physiological measurements. $Course focuses on non-invasive human experiments supplemented with in vitro tissues experiments to explore fundamental physiological concepts and learn basic methods of physiological measurements

name: Protein Biology
description: $Biological view of proteins, including protein biosynthesis, processing, modification, folding, trafficking, interactions, degradation, natural and directed evolution, assembly diseases, amyloids, prions and protein-based inheritance. $Biological view of proteins, including protein biosynthesis, processing, modification, folding, trafficking, interactions, degradation, natural and directed evolution, assembly diseases, amyloids, prions and protein-based inheritance.

name: Cancer Biology and Biotechnology
description: $This course covers basic concepts of cancer biology and new technologies that are being developed to understand, detect, treat and prevent cancer. $This course covers basic concepts of cancer biology and new technologies that are being developed to understand, detect, treat and prevent cancer.

name: Exercise Physiology
description: $Physiology of human movement with emphasis on metabolic, cardiorespiratory, and musculoskeletal aspects; associated topics include body composition, thermoregulation, and ergogenic aids. $Physiology of human movement with emphasis on metabolic, cardiorespiratory, and musculoskeletal aspects; associated topics include body composition, thermoregulation, and ergogenic aids.

name: Genomics and Applied Bioinformatics
description: $Retrieval and analysis of biological sequence, gene expression, and proteomics data from public databases and other sources; applying standard bioinformatics tools to investigate biological questions. $Retrieval and analysis of biological sequence, gene expression, and proteomics data from public databases and other sources; applying standard bioinformatics tools to investigate biological questions.

name: Kinesiological Basis of Human Movement
description: $This course teaches principles related to the biomechanics, energetics and motor control of movement as it applies to human and animal movement, rehabilitation, and sports performance. $This course teaches principles related to the biomechanics, energetics and motor control of movement as it applies to human and animal movement, rehabilitation, and sports performance.

name: Biological Oceanography
description: $An introduction to the major biological processes in the ocean including primary production, elemental cycling, food webs, and fisheries. $An introduction to the major biological processes in the ocean including primary production, elemental cycling, food webs, and fisheries.

name: Molecular Evolution
description: $Evolutionary processes at molecular level, organization of genomes and genetic systems. Students will read and present up-to-date research articles in various topics in molecular evolution. $Evolutionary processes at molecular level, organization of genomes and genetic systems. Students will read and present up-to-date research articles in various topics in molecular evolution.

name: Ion Channels in Health and Disease
description: $We will examine the basic biophysical properties, structure-function relationships, physiological regulation, pathology and pharmacological manipulation of ion channels with heavy reliance on recent literature. $We will examine the basic biophysical properties, structure-function relationships, physiological regulation, pathology and pharmacological manipulation of ion channels with heavy reliance on recent literature.

name: Medical Microbiology
description: $Advanced study of bacteria, protozoa, fungi, and viruses that cause human diseases; emphasis on epidemiology, mechanisms of disease causation, prevention, and treatment. $Advanced study of bacteria, protozoa, fungi, and viruses that cause human diseases; emphasis on epidemiology, mechanisms of disease causation, prevention, and treatment.

name: Human Neuroanatomy
description: $The purpose of this course is to learn the anatomical makeup of the human nervous system.  In this course we will closely examine details of central and peripheral neuroanatomy with links to function.  As well, comparisons with non-human vertebrate neuroanatomy will be made. $The purpose of this course is to learn the anatomical makeup of the human nervous system.  In this course we will closely examine details of central and peripheral neuroanatomy with links to function.  As well, comparisons with non-human vertebrate neuroanatomy will be made.

name: Experimental Design and Statistical Methods in Biological Sciences
description: $Introductory course on experimental design, hypothesis testing and basic statistical techniques commonly applied in biosciences research. Exercises based on statistical software packages. $Introductory course on experimental design, hypothesis testing and basic statistical techniques commonly applied in biosciences research. Exercises based on statistical software packages.

name: Microbial Ecology
description: $Advanced studies of microbial ecosystems, the specific roles of bacteria in maintaining ecological balance, and the evolution of the ecosystem in response to changing environments. $Advanced studies of microbial ecosystems, the specific roles of bacteria in maintaining ecological balance, and the evolution of the ecosystem in response to changing environments.

name: Marine Ecology
description: $An overview of the physical forces and biotic interactions structuring marine communities and of the major threats to these communities. $An overview of the physical forces and biotic interactions structuring marine communities and of the major threats to these communities

name: Microbial Physiology
description: $Study of the physiology of growth and metabolic activities of microorganisms. $Study of the physiology of growth and metabolic activities of microorganisms.

name: Population Dynamics
description: $Students will examine the ecological factors that affect dynamics, regulation, and evolution of natural populations, emphasizing the connections with mathematical models, genetics, and ecology. $Students will examine the ecological factors that affect dynamics, regulation, and evolution of natural populations, emphasizing the connections with mathematical models, genetics, and ecology.

name: Conservation Biology
description: $This course explores the broad diversity of disciplines in conservation, with emphasis on biological phenomena. Analyzes contemporary issues affecting biodiversity, extinction risk, and policymaking.

name: Human Pathology
description: $The course provides a comprehensive overview of clinical human anatomic pathology. The course will focus on select diseases and their etiologies, pathogenesis, morphological changes, and clinical manifestations. $The course provides a comprehensive overview of clinical human anatomic pathology. The course will focus on select diseases and their etiologies, pathogenesis, morphological changes, and clinical manifestations.

name: Communicating Biological Research
description: $Students learn to convey the importance of research findings in the biological sciences and to critically evaluate research results through discussions and scientific presentations. $Students learn to convey the importance of research findings in the biological sciences and to critically evaluate research results through discussions and scientific presentations.

name: Developmental Biology
description: $Investigation of cell differentiation and development, using the tools of molecular genetics and cell biology. $Investigation of cell differentiation and development, using the tools of molecular genetics and cell biology.

name: Evolutionary Developmental Biology – How to Build an Organism
description: $This course teaches students how the process of development from embryo to adult impacts evolutionary diversity and human health. $This course teaches students how the process of development from embryo to adult impacts evolutionary diversity and human health.

name: Drug Discovery
description: $You will learn about the drug discovery process by identifying a disease and disease target,  and then design a therapy to treat the disease. $You will learn about the drug discovery process by identifying a disease and disease target,  and then design a therapy to treat the disease.

description: $This course introduces students to the basics of coding, applied to fundamental biological and medical questions. $This course introduces students to the basics of coding, applied to fundamental biological and medical questions.

name: Epigenetics,  Stem Cells, and Development

name: Human Motor Control

name: Introduction to Environmental Science
description: $Introduction to environmental field science. Case study approach. Exposure to basic field equipment and techniques, analysis of data. $Introduction to environmental field science. Case study approach. Exposure to basic field equipment and techniques, analysis of data.

name: Habitable Planet
description: $Introduction to the origin and evolution of Planet Earth, creation of the universe and the elements, early history of Earth, radioisotope geochemistry and the timing of events in the universe, the galaxy, and on Earth. Formation of the atmosphere and oceans. Climate. $Introduction to the origin and evolution of Planet Earth, creation of the universe and the elements, early history of Earth, radioisotope geochemistry and the timing of events in the universe, the galaxy, and on Earth. Formation of the atmosphere and oceans. Climate.

name: Earth and Atmospheric Sciences Elective
description: $ $1.000 TO    21.000 Credit hours

name: Environmental Measures of Urban and Regional Change
description: $Identify and quantify nature's physical and chemical contributions to human-made urban environments, and measure the impacts of urban area feedback on these natural systems. $Identify and quantify nature's physical and chemical contributions to human-made urban environments, and measure the impacts of urban area feedback on these natural systems.

name: Introduction to Meteorological Analysis
description: $An introduction to analysis of forecasting data and moel output. $An introduction to analysis of forecasting data and moel output.

name: Earth Processes
description: $An introduction to earth materials and processes. $An introduction to earth materials and processes.

name: Earth Through Time
description: $Dynamic processes affecting the Earth system on all time scales. $Dynamic processes affecting the Earth system on all time scales.

name: Quantitative Techniques in Earth and Atmospheric Sciences
description: $Integrated course in mathematical, physical, and computing techniques for applications in earth and atmospheric sciences. $Integrated course in mathematical, physical, and computing techniques for applications in earth and atmospheric sciences.

name: Internship Assistantship
description: $Earth & Atmospheric Sciences Undergraduate Internship for pay for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Earth & Atmospheric Sciences. $Earth & Atmospheric Sciences Undergraduate Internship for pay for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Earth & Atmospheric Sciences.

name: Undergraduate Internship
description: $Earth & Atmospheric Sciences Undergraduate Internship for credit for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Earth & Atmospheric Sciences. $Earth & Atmospheric Sciences Undergraduate Internship for credit for freshmen and sophomores, by permit only. The internship experience must be at a unit or agency approved by the School of Earth & Atmospheric Sciences.

name: Research Assistantship
description: $ $1.000 TO    12.000 Credit hours

name: Undergraduate Research
description: $Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member. $Independent research conducted under the guidance of a faculty member.

name: Physics of the Weather
description: $An introductory treatment of the application of the basic physical laws to the understanding of weather phenomena. Crosslisted with PHYS 2750. $An introductory treatment of the application of the basic physical laws to the understanding of weather phenomena. Crosslisted with PHYS 2750.

name: Special Topics
description: $ $1.000 Credit hours

name: Special Topics
description: $ $2.000 Credit hours

name: Special Topics
description: $ $3.000 Credit hours

name: Special Topics
description: $ $4.000 Credit hours

name: Special Problems
description: $ $1.000 TO    21.000 Credit hours

name: Earth and Atmospheric Sciences Elective
description: $ $1.000 TO    21.000 Credit hours

name: Energy, Environment, and Society
description: $This course analyzes the path towards alternative energy infrastructures for the 21st century with careful consideration of economic, environmental, technological, and political factors. $This course analyzes the path towards alternative energy infrastructures for the 21st century with careful consideration of economic, environmental, technological, and political factors.

name: Thermodynamics of Earth Systems
description: $Introduction to the principles of equilinrium thermodynamics and physical chemistry with applications to the atmosphere, ocean, and solid earth. $Introduction to the principles of equilinrium thermodynamics and physical chemistry with applications to the atmosphere, ocean, and solid earth.

name: Introduction to Geophysics
description: $An introduction to visualizing and understanding earth history, structure, and dynamics through geophysical methods including seismology, gravity, magnetism, heat flow, geochronology, and geodesy. $An introduction to visualizing and understanding earth history, structure, and dynamics through geophysical methods including seismology, gravity, magnetism, heat flow, geochronology, and geodesy.

name: Geochemistry
description: $A quantitative treatment of geochemical processes in the Earth and natural waters, with emphasis on chemical reactions among atmospheric gases, minerals, and aqueous solutions. $A quantitative treatment of geochemical processes in the Earth and natural waters, with emphasis on chemical reactions among atmospheric gases, minerals, and aqueous solutions.

name: Special Topics
description: $ $3.000 Credit hours

name: Earth and Atmospheric Sciences Elective
description: $ $1.000 TO    21.000 Credit hours

name: Resources, Energy and the Environment
description: $Learn about the science behind the nature, occurrence and extraction of earth resources used by humans and the environmental impacts of that use. $Learn about the science behind the nature, occurrence and extraction of earth resources used by humans and the environmental impacts of that use.

name: Structural Geology and Continuum Mechanics
description: $Structural geology and continuum mechanics for scientists and civil engineers. Stress and strain in rocks; faults, joints, and folds; basic field mapping; laboratory exercises. $Structural geology and continuum mechanics for scientists and civil engineers. Stress and strain in rocks; faults, joints, and folds; basic field mapping; laboratory exercises.

name: Geomorphology
description: $Overview of the mechanical, chemical, and biological processes that shape topography. $Overview of the mechanical, chemical, and biological processes that shape topography.

name: Environmental Geochemistry
description: $An exploration of the chemical, biological, and geological processes controlling the distribution of chemical nutrients and pollutants in aquatic and soil environments. $An exploration of the chemical, biological, and geological processes controlling the distribution of chemical nutrients and pollutants in aquatic and soil environments.

name: Environmental Geochemistry Lab
description: $Lab and field exploration of the chemical, biological, and geological processes controlling the distribution of chemical nutrients and pollutants in aquatic and soil environments. $Lab and field exploration of the chemical, biological, and geological processes controlling the distribution of chemical nutrients and pollutants in aquatic and soil environments.

name: Mineral Surface Geochemistry
description: $Fundamental principles concerning mineral surface properties, element distribution at the mineral-water interface and analytical techniques relevant to interfacial reactions. $Fundamental principles concerning mineral surface properties, element distribution at the mineral-water interface and analytical techniques relevant to interfacial reactions.

name: Introduction to Physical and Chemical Oceanography
description: $Chemistry and physics of the ocean. Distributions of temperature, salinity, and density. Equations of state and motion. Surface and deep-water circulation.  Waves and tides. Composition of seawater: dissolved sales, gases, and nutrients. Biological processes. Marine sediments. $Chemistry and physics of the ocean. Distributions of temperature, salinity, and density. Equations of state and motion. Surface and deep-water circulation.  Waves and tides. Composition of seawater: dissolved sales, gases, and nutrients. Biological processes. Marine sediments.

name: Physical and Chemical Oceanography
description: $Study of the dynamics of large-scale ocean circulation, air-sea interaction and their roles in biogeochemical cycling of carbon and nutrients. $Study of the dynamics of large-scale ocean circulation, air-sea interaction and their roles in biogeochemical cycling of carbon and nutrients.

name: Geodynamics
description: $Quantitative discussion of dynamic processs in the solid Earth; lithospheric dynamics, continuum mechanics, lithospheric flexure and elasticity, heat transfer, viscous rheology, fluid mechanics, and earthquake dynamics.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4312 and EAS 6312. $Quantitative discussion of dynamic processs in the solid Earth; lithospheric dynamics, continuum mechanics, lithospheric flexure and elasticity, heat transfer, viscous rheology, fluid mechanics, and earthquake dynamics.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4312 and EAS 6312.

name: Tectonics
description: $Introduction to the interactions and feedbacks between tectonics and climate that act to shape landscapes. Includes field- and computer-based data collection and analysis.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4313 and EAS 6313. $Introduction to the interactions and feedbacks between tectonics and climate that act to shape landscapes. Includes field- and computer-based data collection and analysis.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4313 and EAS 6313.

name: Seismology
description: $Introduction to elastic wave propagation, and studies of the solid Earth's interior and earthquake source from seismic waves.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4314 and EAS 6314. $Introduction to elastic wave propagation, and studies of the solid Earth's interior and earthquake source from seismic waves.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4314 and EAS 6314.

name: Geofluids
description: $This course focuses on the fundamental concepts of fluid dynamics merged with geophysical applications. $This course focuses on the fundamental concepts of fluid dynamics merged with geophysical applications.

name: Earthquake Physics
description: $Fundamental physics of processes that control fault slips and earthquakes with a focus on the latest emerging research topics in the field. $Fundamental physics of processes that control fault slips and earthquakes with a focus on the latest emerging research topics in the field.

name: Physical Volcanology
description: $This class examines the dynamics and thermodynamics of planetary volcanism.  The course material covers the generation and transport of magma in the mantle and crust, and the fluid dynamics of eruptions and their impact on the landscape and atmosphere.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4331 and EAS 6331. $This class examines the dynamics and thermodynamics of planetary volcanism.  The course material covers the generation and transport of magma in the mantle and crust, and the fluid dynamics of eruptions and their impact on the landscape and atmosphere.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4331 and EAS 6331.

name: Paleoclimatology and Paleoceanography
description: $This course will explore the history of the Earth's climate, covering methods for reconstructing past climate and the mechanisms behind these climate changes. $This course will explore the history of the Earth's climate, covering methods for reconstructing past climate and the mechanisms behind these climate changes.

name: Space Physics and Space Instrumentation
description: $This course will explore the interaction of the solar wind with the Earth's magnetosphere using a combination spacecraft observations and fundamental plasma physics.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4360 and EAS 6360. $This course will explore the interaction of the solar wind with the Earth's magnetosphere using a combination spacecraft observations and fundamental plasma physics.  Credit not allowed for both EAS 4360 and EAS 6360.

name: Physics of Planets
description: $In this course we will study the forces and influences that determine the composition, structure and evolution of the planets in our solar system. $In this course we will study the forces and influences that determine the composition, structure and evolution of the planets in our solar system.

name: Earth and Planetary Materials
description: $Fundamental principles and applications of mineralogy and petrology for understanding the composition of surface and subsurface materials on Earth and other planetary bodies. $Fundamental principles and applications of mineralogy and petrology for understanding the composition of surface and subsurface materials on Earth and other planetary bodies.

name: Land Remote Sensing
description: $Techniques for making remote measurements of the composition, morphology, and thermophysical properties of solid surfaces on Earth and other planetary bodies. $Techniques for making remote measurements of the composition, morphology, and thermophysical properties of solid surfaces on Earth and other planetary bodies.

name: Climate and Global Change

name: Economic Analysis and Policy Problems
description: $Practice in analysis of decision problems of relevance to students in public policy and personal decision areas. name: Advanced Microeconomic Analysis
description: $Review of important mathematical tools and techniques used in advanced microeconomics.  Advanced topics include the estimation of demand and cost functions; the role of government in the economy (externalities, property rights, and public goods); public choice theory; factor markets (especially labor and capital markets); models of monopoly; pricing techniques used by firms with market power (monopolies and oligopolies); and game theory. $Review of important mathematical tools and techniques used in advanced microeconomics. name: Advanced Macroeconomic Analysis
description: $Develops theories and models of income and output determination in the open economy. Students explore the impacts of fiscal and monetary policies changes on aggregate economic outcomes. $Develops theories and models of income and output determination in the open economy. Students explore the impacts of fiscal and monetary policies changes on aggregate economic outcomes.

name: Economic and Financial Modeling
description: $Develops student ability to model the essential elements of the investment decision through the use of a valuation model and spreadsheet analysis. Expands upon basic knowledge of present value analysis to recognize risk, growth, capital markets, and market valuation of ongoing operations. $Develops student ability to model the essential elements of the investment decision through the use of a valuation model and spreadsheet analysis. Expands upon basic knowledge of present value analysis to recognize risk, growth, capital markets, and market valuation of ongoing operations.

name: Introduction to Empirical Economics: Data Visualization, Analysis, and Presentation
description: $Develops student abilities to logically formulate economic issues; identify and collect data; analyze the data using spreadsheet and presentation software; generate sound and defensible conclusions and recommendations; and make effective presentations of analysis and conclusions. $Develops student abilities to logically formulate economic issues; identify and collect data; analyze the data using spreadsheet and presentation software; generate sound and defensible conclusions and recommendations; and make effective presentations of analysis and conclusions.

name: Econometric Analysis
description: $Econometric techniques and applications in economic and business analysis.  Practical issues involving modeling, estimation, hypothesis testing, and emphasizing computer implementation through econometric software. $Econometric techniques and applications in economic and business analysis.  Practical issues involving modeling, estimation, hypothesis testing, and emphasizing computer implementation through econometric software.

name: Economics of International Energy Markets
description: $Examines the economics of energy markets, encompassing the full value chain from production to consumption. Covers all major primary energy resources, including fossil fuels, nuclear, hydroelectric, and renewables, as well as electricity and transportation fuel markets. The course highlights health and environmental impacts, regulation and industrial organization, and energy policy at both the state and federal levels. $Examines the economics of energy markets, encompassing the full value chain from production to consumption. Covers all major primary energy resources, including fossil fuels, nuclear, hydroelectric, and renewables, as well as electricity and transportation fuel markets. The course highlights health and environmental impacts, regulation and industrial organization, and energy policy at both the state and federal levels.

name: Economics Elective
description: $ $1.000 TO    21.000 Credit hours

name: Coding and Data Analysis for Economics I
description: $This is the first in the series of three courses on data and empirical techniques used in economic analysis. Data cleaning, data management, and descriptive statistics methods are presented and applied to a variety of economics problems. The course prepares students for extensive use of statistical software to build data management skills and generate reports used in descriptive and explorative data analyses. $This is the first in the series of three courses on data and empirical techniques used in economic analysis. Data cleaning, data management, and descriptive statistics methods are presented and applied to a variety of economics problems. The course prepares students for extensive use of statistical software to build data management skills and generate reports used in descriptive and explorative data analyses.

name: Coding and Data Analysis for Economics II
description: $This is the second in the series of three courses on data and empirical techniques used in economic analysis. The course focuses on advanced skills that include large data management and manipulation, relational data management, extensive vertical and horizonal summative and remerging techniques to prepare data sets for advanced statistical and econometric analyses. $This is the second in the series of three courses on data and empirical techniques used in economic analysis. The course focuses on advanced skills that include large data management and manipulation, relational data management, extensive vertical and horizonal summative and remerging techniques to prepare data sets for advanced statistical and econometric analyses.

name: Coding and Data Analysis for Economics III
description: $This is the third in the series of three courses on data and empirical techniques used in economic analysis. The course trains students to routinise their statistical programming and data analysis skills, such as analysis of variance, linear and logistic regression modelling, and evaluating model performance. This course is an ideal complement to Empirical Methods, various thesis-focused and other research-oriented courses. $This is the third in the series of three courses on data and empirical techniques used in economic analysis. The course trains students to routinise their statistical programming and data analysis skills, such as analysis of variance, linear and logistic regression modelling, and evaluating model performance. This course is an ideal complement to Empirical Methods, various thesis-focused and other research-oriented courses.

name: Career Development Workshop
description: $This workshop style class for economics majors focuses on strategies and skills for identifying career and graduate school pathways, conducting successful job and internship searches, and advancing in the workplace. $This workshop style class for economics majors focuses on strategies and skills for identifying career and graduate school pathways, conducting successful job and internship searches, and advancing in the workplace.

name: Money and Capital Markets
description: $Examines the role of money in macroeconomic activity and the impacts of monetary institutions and policy strategy on the behavior of financial markets and aggregate economic activity. $Examines the role of money in macroeconomic activity and the impacts of monetary institutions and policy strategy on the behavior of financial markets and aggregate economic activity.

name: Economic Forecasting
description: $Surveys modern time series econometrics with topics such as univariate models, vector autoregressions, linear and nonlinear filtering, frequency domain methods, unit roots, structural breaks, empirical process theory asymptotics, and forecasting. The course highlights applications in macroeconomics and finance. $Surveys modern time series econometrics with topics such as univariate models, vector autoregressions, linear and nonlinear filtering, frequency domain methods, unit roots, structural breaks, empirical process theory asymptotics, and forecasting. The course highlights applications in macroeconomics and finance.

name: Machine Learning for Economics
description: $Introduction to the use of Machine Learning in economic analysis. Students will learn popular Machine Learning techniques and the application of these tools in economics. $Introduction to the use of Machine Learning in economic analysis. Students will learn popular Machine Learning techniques and the application of these tools in economics.

name: Mathematics for Economic Modeling
description: $Applies mathematical tools to economic analysis. Topics include the uses of linear algebra, multivariable calculus, comparative-static analysis, and optimization in economics. $Applies mathematical tools to economic analysis. Topics include the uses of linear algebra, multivariable calculus, comparative-static analysis, and optimization in economics.

name: Game Theory I
description: $Course covers static games of complete information, dynamic games of complete information, static games of incomplete information and dynamic games of incomplete information. $Course covers static games of complete information, dynamic games of complete information, static games of incomplete information and dynamic games of incomplete information.

name: Game Theory II
description: $Students will learn microeconomic theories of strategic decision making by firms and individuals, and how firms and individuals utilize information to interact strategically. $Students will learn microeconomic theories of strategic decision making by firms and individuals, and how firms and individuals utilize information to interact strategically.

name: The Economics of Climate Change
description: $This course will explore the economic causes and consequences of climate change and evaluate the suite of policy options to mitigate greenhouse-gas emissions. $This course will explore the economic causes and consequences of climate change and evaluate the suite of policy options to mitigate greenhouse-gas emissions.

name: Labor Economics
description: $Introduces students to labor markets, government regulations, and the incentives and behavior of workers and firms.  Topics include wage discrimination, minimum-wage laws, and unemployment. $Introduces students to labor markets, government regulations, and the incentives and behavior of workers and firms.  Topics include wage discrimination, minimum-wage laws, and unemployment.

name: Economics of Information, Transactions Costs, and Contracts
description: $Builds from analysis of the individual in a trading or transaction situation to study organizations as groups of affiliated individuals.  Assesses the situations when organizations are preferable to markets as forms of organizing economic and social activity.  Institutional economics and transaction cost economics are studied. Analysis of corporate restructuring and privatization. $Builds from analysis of the individual in a trading or transaction situation to study organizations as groups of affiliated individuals.  Assesses the situations when organizations are preferable to markets as forms of organizing economic and social activity.  Institutional economics and transaction cost economics are studied. Analysis of corporate restructuring and privatization.

name: Strategic Economics for Global Enterprise
description: $Examines the strategies, decisions, and operations of multinational enterprises in a fast-changing global environment. The course examines theories of trade, foreign direct investment, competition, firm strategy, and the macroeconomic environment and their implications for location decisions and growth of multinational firms. $Examines the strategies, decisions, and operations of multinational enterprises in a fast-changing global environment. The course examines theories of trade, foreign direct investment, competition, firm strategy, and the macroeconomic environment and their implications for location decisions and growth of multinational firms.

name: Economics of Technology, Innovation, and Entrepreneurship
description: $Analyzes the economics of entrepreneurship and innovation. Topics include the business and economic history of entrepreneurship as well as the legal and institutional framework of the entrepreneurial environment. $Analyzes the economics of entrepreneurship and innovation. Topics include the business and economic history of entrepreneurship as well as the legal and institutional framework of the entrepreneurial environment.

name: Economics of Industrial Competition
description: $This course examines the theory of the firm, the relationship between market structure, practices, and performance, and the determinants of technological change. The role (and ability) of government policy to solve various market failures, via antitrust enforcement, regulation, etc., is also discussed. $This course examines the theory of the firm, the relationship between market structure, practices, and performance, and the determinants of technological change. The role (and ability) of government policy to solve various market failures, via antitrust enforcement, regulation, etc., is also discussed.

name: Economic Regulation
description: $This course examines how government economically regulates private industry, how it might regulate more efficiently, and when it should not regulate at all.  General theories of antitrust enforcement and economic regulation are developed and applied to a variety of industry cases. $This course examines how government economically regulates private industry, how it might regulate more efficiently, and when it should not regulate at all.  General theories of antitrust enforcement and economic regulation are developed and applied to a variety of industry cases.

name: International Economics
description: $Covers important topics in trade theory, trade policy, and international finance. The course emphasizes the use of economic tools to analyze a variety of current events in the world economy. $Covers important topics in trade theory, trade policy, and international finance. The course emphasizes the use of economic tools to analyze a variety of current events in the world economy.

name: International Financial Economics
description: $This course familiarizes students with concepts, models, theories and applications in international markets. $This course familiarizes students with concepts, models, theories and applications in international markets.

name: International Trade Theory and Policy
description: $This course will develop a theoretical framework to understand international trade. Students will examine the possibility of gains from trade, the nature of comparative advantage, the determination of the pattern of trade, the role of scale economies, imperfect competition, and factor movements. Students will examine trade policy, in particular the effects of protection (tariffs and non-tariff barriers) on prices and domestic consumer and producer economic welfare. $This course will develop a theoretical framework to understand international trade. Students will examine the possibility of gains from trade, the nature of comparative advantage, the determination of the pattern of trade, the role of scale economies, imperfect competition, and factor movements. Students will examine trade policy, in particular the effects of protection (tariffs and non-tariff barriers) on prices and domestic consumer and producer economic welfare.

name: Global Financial Economics
description: $Examines the global system of markets and institutions for the exchange of capital, money, and goods. The course studies the impact of globalization on national economies and fundamental economic global relationships. $Examines the global system of markets and institutions for the exchange of capital, money, and goods. The course studies the impact of globalization on national economies and fundamental economic global relationships.

name: Law and Economics of the Global Trading System
description: $This course takes an interdisciplinary approach, examining the economics, law, and political economy of the global trading system and its rules and practices. The course reviews the main economic theories behind the existence of tariffs, quotas, subsidies, non-tariff barriers to trade, strategic trade policies, and discusses the basic rules of GATT and World Trade Organization (WTO). Case-study discussions are used to analyze how multinational enterprises (MNEs) alter their strategies and decision-making structures in response to multilateral rules and enforcement mechanisms embodied in the WTO. $This course takes an interdisciplinary approach, examining the economics, law, and political economy of the global trading system and its rules and practices. The course reviews the main economic theories behind the existence of tariffs, quotas, subsidies, non-tariff barriers to trade, strategic trade policies, and discusses the basic rules of GATT and World Trade Organization (WTO). Case-study discussions are used to analyze how multinational enterprises (MNEs) alter their strategies and decision-making structures in response to multilateral rules and enforcement mechanisms embodied in the WTO.

name: Economics of Telecommunication Networks and E-commerce
description: $Analyzes the telecommunications sector from the public policy, business strategy, and technology perspectives. The course explores the driving forces behind the radical change in telecommunications regulations and the impact of this regulation on business operations. $Analyzes the telecommunications sector from the public policy, business strategy, and technology perspectives. The course explores the driving forces behind the radical change in telecommunications regulations and the impact of this regulation on business operations.

name: Law and Economics
description: $To introduce students to economic aspects of legal decision-making and to develop students' ability to critically analyze the purposes and efficiency of legal decision-making from an economic perspective. $To introduce students to economic aspects of legal decision-making and to develop students' ability to critically analyze the purposes and efficiency of legal decision-making from an economic perspective.

name: Behavioral Economics
description: $Human psychology and the rational choice models of economics are joined to better understand human decision-making.  Students will design and execute their own experiments. $Human psychology and the rational choice models of economics are joined to better understand human decision-making.  Students will design and execute their own experiments.

name: Economic Development
description: $Introduces models of economic growth and sustainable development with a focus on inequality and poverty in the national and global context. $Introduces models of economic growth and sustainable development with a focus on inequality and poverty in the national and global context.

name: Cost-Benefit Analysis
description: $Introduces students to the principles, tools, issues, strengths, and limitations of cost-benefit analysis (CBA). The course prepares students to competently review, criticize, and use CBA studies. $Introduces students to the principles, tools, issues, strengths, and limitations of cost-benefit analysis (CBA). The course prepares students to competently review, criticize, and use CBA studies.

name: Conflict and Security in Developing Countries
description: $Introduces research on the causes and consequences of contemporary armed conflict as well as economic studies of terrorism. $Introduces research on the causes and consequences of contemporary armed conflict as well as economic studies of terrorism.

name: Urban and Regional Economics
description: $Introduces the economics of regions, cities, and space. Students learn theories of growth and location to analyze the effects of urbanization, agglomeration, and congestion. The course analyzes public policy relating to urban and regional problems. $Introduces the economics of regions, cities, and space. Students learn theories of growth and location to analyze the effects of urbanization, agglomeration, and congestion. The course analyzes public policy relating to urban and regional problems.

name: Economics of Transportation and Communication Systems
description: $Covers fundamentals of transport demand and supply, markets, infrastructure, and transport-related externalities. Empirical case studies explore current topics in transport sectors (e.g. the airline, rail, and highway sectors). $Covers fundamentals of transport demand and supply, markets, infrastructure, and transport-related externalities. Empirical case studies explore current topics in transport sectors (e.g. the airline, rail, and highway sectors).

name: Economics of Natural Resources and the Environment
description: $Explores how economics can address a variety of environmental issues ranging from climate change to local pollution. Topic areas include externalities and the social costs of pollution, valuation of non-market goods, climate change policy (emissions taxes and cap-and-trade), management of renewable resources (fisheries and forests), extraction of exhaustible resources (minerals and fossil fuels), and more. Focuses on global, regional, and local environmental policy. $Explores how economics can address a variety of environmental issues ranging from climate change to local pollution. Topic areas include externalities and the social costs of pollution, valuation of non-market goods, climate change policy (emissions taxes and cap-and-trade), management of renewable resources (fisheries and forests), extraction of exhaustible resources (minerals and fossil fuels), and more. Focuses on global, regional, and local environmental policy.

name: Topics in African American Entrepreneurship
description: $History and dynamics of African-American business. Impact of racial segregation on business formation.  Case studies and empirical exercises. $History and dynamics of African-American business. Impact of racial segregation on business formation.  Case studies and empirical exercises.

name: Public Economics
description: $Applies tools of microeconomics to the public sector. Explores the role of the government in the economy, providing an understanding of the reasons for government intervention in markets, the merits of possible government policies, and the response of economic agents to the government’s actions. Topics covered include tax policy, externalities, public goods, and social insurance programs. Emphasis is placed on contemporary policy debates, such as income and wealth inequality, social security reform, climate policy, health care reform, and education policy. $Applies tools of microeconomics to the public sector. Explores the role of the government in the economy, providing an understanding of the reasons for government intervention in markets, the merits of possible government policies, and the response of economic agents to the government’s actions. Topics covered include tax policy, externalities, public goods, and social insurance programs. Emphasis is placed on contemporary policy debates, such as income and wealth inequality, social security reform, climate policy, health care reform, and education policy.

name: Economics of Health and Health Care
description: $Surveys theoretical and empirical evidence on current issues in health and health care. The course presents individual-level models of health behaviors and the demand for health and medical insurance. Students analyze the economic behaviors of physicians, hospitals, and insurance companies as well as the possible role of government in encouraging the equitable and efficient performance of health markets. The course emphasizes current debates involving individual health decisions, health care reform, and the diffusion of new medical technologies. $Surveys theoretical and empirical evidence on current issues in health and health care. The course presents individual-level models of health behaviors and the demand for health and medical insurance. Students analyze the economic behaviors of physicians, hospitals, and insurance companies as well as the possible role of government in encouraging the equitable and efficient performance of health markets. The course emphasizes current debates involving individual health decisions, health care reform, and the diffusion of new medical technologies.

name: Economics of Sports
description: $Uses economic principles from game theory, labor economics, and econometrics to analyze a wide range of issues in the realms of professional sports and collegiate athletics. $Uses economic principles from game theory, labor economics, and econometrics to analyze a wide range of issues in the realms of professional sports and collegiate athletics.

name: Seminar in Economic Policy
description: $The objective of the course is to enable students to interpret current economic problems and policies using the economic models learned in their theory courses.  Students study the current "Economic Report of the President" and apply analytical tools to the data included in the text. name: History of Economic Thought
description: $This course is concerned with the economists who interpreted and influenced the development of capitalism and socialism over the last two centuries. $This course is concerned with the economists who interpreted and influenced the development of capitalism and socialism over the last two centuries.

description: $This course covers fundamental quantitative tools used in economic and econometric analysis, which includes topics in differential calculus, optimization, and linear algebra. $This course covers fundamental quantitative tools used in economic and econometric analysis, which includes topics in differential calculus, optimization, and linear algebra.

name: Econometrics I
description: $This course gives students the necessary background for taking courses in the econometrics sequence.  Topics include descriptive statistics, continuous and discrete probability distributions, parameter estimation, one- and two-sample hypothesis testing, and bivariate regression models. $This course gives students the necessary background for taking courses in the econometrics sequence.  Topics include descriptive statistics, continuous and discrete probability distributions, parameter estimation, one- and two-sample hypothesis testing, and bivariate regression models.

name: Cost-Benefit Analysis
description: $The application of economic, financial, and quantitative reasoning and tools to issues of resource allocation and policy, primarily in the public sector. $The application of economic, financial, and quantitative reasoning and tools to issues of resource allocation and policy, primarily in the public sector.

name: Econometrics II
description: $This course introduces advanced econometric methods on estimation and testing, including instrumental variable estimation, panel data analysis, limited dependent variable models, and simultaneous equation system.  The course emphasizes applications of these techniques to real-world problems using professional software packages. $This course introduces advanced econometric methods on estimation and testing, including instrumental variable estimation, panel data analysis, limited dependent variable models, and simultaneous equation system.  The course emphasizes applications of these techniques to real-world problems using professional software packages.

name: Econometric Modeling and Forecasting
description: $This course introduces techniques on economic and business forecasting, focusing on regression analysis and ARIMA models.  Testing for unit roots and cointegration are also discussed.  Professional software packages for forecasting are used in applications. $This course introduces techniques on economic and business forecasting, focusing on regression analysis and ARIMA models.  Testing for unit roots and cointegration are also discussed.  Professional software packages for forecasting are used in applications.

name: Discrete Choice Econometrics
description: $Focuses on econometric methods for which the dependent variable represents an "either-or" choice.  Included in the set of topics are binary and multinomial logic, ordered choice, heteroskedastic extreme value, bivariate and multivariate probit, nested logit structures, discrete/continuous, and Poisson models.  The course includes numerous applications using professional software programs. $Focuses on econometric methods for which the dependent variable represents an "either-or" choice.  Included in the set of topics are binary and multinomial logic, ordered choice, heteroskedastic extreme value, bivariate and multivariate probit, nested logit structures, discrete/continuous, and Poisson models.  The course includes numerous applications using professional software programs.

name: Money and Capital Markets
description: $The role of money in the exchange process, Federal Reserve strategy, and the impact of monetary policy on financial markets and aggregate economic activity. $The role of money in the exchange process, Federal Reserve strategy, and the impact of monetary policy on financial markets and aggregate economic activity.

name: Corporate Value Chains and Transfer Pricing
description: $We analyze value chains that firms use to globally produce goods, services, and intangibles and apply microeconomic models to price and analyze value chain components. $We analyze value chains that firms use to globally produce goods, services, and intangibles and apply microeconomic models to price and analyze value chain components.

name: Public Economics
description: $An examination of public goods, public decision making, voting, free riders, taxation principles, welfare, the Tiebout Hypothesis, budgeting, and fiscal policy. $An examination of public goods, public decision making, voting, free riders, taxation principles, welfare, the Tiebout Hypothesis, budgeting, and fiscal policy.

name: Urban and Regional Economics
description: $Economics of regions, cities, and space.  Theories of growth and location, effects of urbanization, agglomeration, and congestion. Public policy relating to urban and regional problems. $Economics of regions, cities, and space.  Theories of growth and location, effects of urbanization, agglomeration, and congestion. Public policy relating to urban and regional problems.

name: Transportation Economics
description: $Examines the economics of transportation markets, including resource allocation, economic welfare, government regulation, and public policy. Using an econometric case study approach, the course develops the necessary steps for testing hypotheses, analyzing the finding of recent studies, and exploring implications for the development and implementation of transportation policy. $Examines the economics of transportation markets, including resource allocation, economic welfare, government regulation, and public policy. Using an econometric case study approach, the course develops the necessary steps for testing hypotheses, analyzing the finding of recent studies, and exploring implications for the development and implementation of transportation policy.

name: Development Economics
description: $Concepts and models of development and growth in Third World countries, emphasizing modeling and testing of recent changes in the Third World . Topics include economic growth, trade and globalization, poverty and inequity, migration, population growth, unemployment, agricultural development, the environment, and the role of the market versus the state. $Concepts and models of development and growth in Third World countries, emphasizing modeling and testing of recent changes in the Third World . name: Economics of Natural Resources and the Environment
description: $Explores how economics can address a variety of environmental issues ranging from climate change to local pollution. Topic areas include externalities and the social costs of pollution, valuation of non-market goods, climate change policy (emissions taxes and cap-and-trade), management of renewable resources (fisheries and forests), extraction of exhaustible resources (minerals and fossil fuels), and more. Focuses on global, regional, and local environmental policy. $Explores how economics can address a variety of environmental issues ranging from climate change to local pollution. Focuses on global, regional, and local environmental policy.

name: Strategic Economics for Global Enterprise
description: $This course uses economic tools to examine strategic aspects of competition and collaboration in an integrated global market.  Topics include the determinants and changes in the boundaries of global firms, competitive advantage and value creation, the nature of global markets, and strategic positioning in the global market place. $This course uses economic tools to examine strategic aspects of competition and collaboration in an integrated global market.  Topics include the determinants and changes in the boundaries of global firms, competitive advantage and value creation, the nature of global markets, and strategic positioning in the global market place.

name: The Economics of Technology, Innovation, and Entrpreneurship
description: $This course explores the impact that innovation, technology progress, and R&D activities have upon a firm's pricing and output behavior.  Based upon computer case studies, biotechnology, and telecommunications sectors, the course further analyzes the economic role that firm size and entrepreneurial opportunities play in technological development and innovation. $This course explores the impact that innovation, technology progress, and R&D activities have upon a firm's pricing and output behavior.  Based upon computer case studies, biotechnology, and telecommunications sectors, the course further analyzes the economic role that firm size and entrepreneurial opportunities play in technological development and innovation.

name: Topics in African American Entrepreneurship
description: $Explores African-American entrepreneurship from the ante-bellum period to the present.  Implications of economic and socio-political developments are given particular attention, including the urbanization of blacks, the rise of benevolent societies following slavery, institutionalization of Jim Crow segregation, desegregation, and affirmative action's role in an emerging class of black entrepreneurs. $Explores African-American entrepreneurship from the ante-bellum period to the present.  Implications of economic and socio-political developments are given particular attention, including the urbanization of blacks, the rise of benevolent societies following slavery, institutionalization of Jim Crow segregation, desegregation, and affirmative action's role in an emerging class of black entrepreneurs.

name: Industrial Organization
description: $This course examines modern theories of the firm, market power, and competitive strategy.  Game theory is employed throughout the course. $This course examines modern theories of the firm, market power, and competitive strategy.  Game theory is employed throughout the course.

name: Economics of Health and Health Care
description: $A critical survey of the current theoretical and empirical issues involving the economics of health and health care. $A critical survey of the current theoretical and empirical issues involving the economics of health and health care.

name: Seminar in Economic Policy
description: $Interprets current economic problems and policies using fundamental economic principles. $Interprets current economic problems and policies using fundamental economic principles.

name: History of Economic Thought
description: $Economists who interpreted and influenced the development of capitalism and socialism over the last two centuries. $Economists who interpreted and influenced the development of capitalism and socialism over the last two centuries.

name: International Economics and Policy Analysis
description: $Explores international economic issues.  The first part examines aspects of international trade, including specialization and exchange, strategy, labor and capital movements, preferential trading arrangements, and economic development.  The second part analyzes international finance, including exchange rates, open economy macro policies, Eurocurrency markets, and the international monetary system. $Explores international economic issues.  The first part examines aspects of international trade, including specialization and exchange, strategy, labor and capital movements, preferential trading arrangements, and economic development.  The second part analyzes international finance, including exchange rates, open economy macro policies, Eurocurrency markets, and the international monetary system.

name: Introduction to Global Development
description: $This course introduces students to the goals, theories and key institutional actors involved in the field of Global Development. $This course introduces students to the goals, theories and key institutional actors involved in the field of Global Development.

name: Mathematics for Economists
description: $Topics include matrix algebra, limits and open sets, implicit functions and their derivatives, quadratic forms and definite matrices, unconstrained and constrained static optimization, dynamic optimization and economic applications. $Topics include matrix algebra, limits and open sets, implicit functions and their derivatives, quadratic forms and definite matrices, unconstrained and constrained static optimization, dynamic optimization and economic applications.

name: Microeconomic Theory I
description: $The topics covered in this course are axiomatic theory of consumer behavior, consumer choice, classical demand theory, aggregate demand, choice under uncertainty, producer theory and partial equilibrium analysis. $The topics covered in this course are axiomatic theory of consumer behavior, consumer choice, classical demand theory, aggregate demand, choice under uncertainty, producer theory and partial equilibrium analysis.

name: Microeconomic Theory II
description: $The subject areas in this course are general equilibrium, welfare economics, externalities, public goods, economics of information and inter-temporal dynamic analysis. $The subject areas in this course are general equilibrium, welfare economics, externalities, public goods, economics of information and inter-temporal dynamic analysis.

name: Game Theory
description: $Static and dynamic games of complete and incomplete information, and mechanism design. Economic applications include Cournot, Bertrand and Stackelberg duopolies, voluntary provision of public goods, auctions, procurement contracts and time inconsistency issues.

name: Econometrics I
description: $This course is a comprehensive introduction to mathematical statistics principles underlying statistical analyses in economics.  It covers probability theory, expectation, sampling, asymptotic results, the main families of probability distributions studied in economics, estimation and hypothesis testing. $This course is a comprehensive introduction to mathematical statistics principles underlying statistical analyses in economics.  It covers probability theory, expectation, sampling, asymptotic results, the main families of probability distributions studied in economics, estimation and hypothesis testing.

name: Econometrics II
description: $Linear and nonlinear regression analyses, hypothesis testing, ordinary and generalized least squares, instrumental variables estimation, the generalized method of moments, the method of maximum likelihood, methods for stationary time series, unit roots and cointegration, and specification testing. $Linear and nonlinear regression analyses, hypothesis testing, ordinary and generalized least squares, instrumental variables estimation, the generalized method of moments, the method of maximum likelihood, methods for stationary time series, unit roots and cointegration, and specification testing.

name: Empirical Research Methods
description: $Topics include up-to-date theory for data analysis, including time series, cross section and panel, and empirical applications using panel data, time series data and cross-sectional data. $Topics include up-to-date theory for data analysis, including time series, cross section and panel, and empirical applications using panel data, time series data and cross-sectional data.

name: Microeconomet Analysis
description: $Focus on empirical microeconometric methods, including binary, multinomial, and ordered response models, and event history models. name: Microeconomics of Innovation
description: $Historical evolution of institutions that promote innovation, knowledge as a public good, prizes and intellectual property rights as incentive mechanisms, models of cumulative innovation, patent and copyright enforcement and litigation, private versus public funding, and the effects introduced by network externalities and globalization issues. $Historical evolution of institutions that promote innovation, knowledge as a public good, prizes and intellectual property rights as incentive mechanisms, models of cumulative innovation, patent and copyright enforcement and litigation, private versus public funding, and the effects introduced by network externalities and globalization issues.

name: Macroeconomics of Innovation
description: $Macroeconomic factors that lead to technological change, the roles played by technological innovation and knowledge spillovers as promoters of economic growth, and the scope for fiscal and monetary policies to foment research and development and hence economic growth. $Macroeconomic factors that lead to technological change, the roles played by technological innovation and knowledge spillovers as promoters of economic growth, and the scope for fiscal and monetary policies to foment research and development and hence economic growth.

name: Environmental Economics I
description: $Topics include externalities, property rights, incentive design, emission taxes, tradable emission permits, renewable and nonrenewable resources, innovation incentives originating with environmental regulations and globalization, trans-boundary polluntants within and across nations, international environmental agreements, and the globalization impacts on the environment. $Topics include externalities, property rights, incentive design, emission taxes, tradable emission permits, renewable and nonrenewable resources, innovation incentives originating with environmental regulations and globalization, trans-boundary polluntants within and across nations, international environmental agreements, and the globalization impacts on the environment.

name: Environmental Economics II
description: $Empirical course, built upon the theoretical topics covered in Environmental Economics I. name: Industrial Organization I

name: Industrial Organization II
description: $Empirical course that trains students to empirically examine the theoretical issues arising in Industrial Organization I. name: International Economics I
description: $Topics include Ricardian and Hecksher-Ohlin models, extensions to many goods and factors, trade in intermediate inputs and wages, increasing returns, gains from trade and regional agreements, import tariffs and dumping, import quotas and export subsidies, political economy of trade policy and trade and endogenous growth. name: International Economics II
description: $Empirical extension of International Economics I, which surveys the empirical literature and presents the key empirical results related to the topics discussed in the theoretical course. Projects must be based on the knowledge and skills acquired in earlier course work, and incorporate appropriate engineering standards and multiple realistic constraints. Emphasis is placed on the design process, the technical aspects of the design, and on reducing the proposed design to practice.  The course consists of faculty and guest lectures, prototyping in design studios, and a multi-disciplinary design project. $Seniors will work in teams to apply a systematic design process to real multi-disciplinary problems. description: $The transformation of the Middle East in the modern era and the relationship of the "East" and "West" in the contemporary world. $The transformation of the Middle East in the modern era and the relationship of the "East" and "West" in the contemporary world.

name: Colonial Latin America and the World
description: $An exploration of colonial Latin America from the perspective of Global History. $An exploration of colonial Latin America from the perspective of Global History.

name: North American Borderlands
description: $Introduction to the history of early Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and California in the Spanish Colonial period. $Introduction to the history of early Florida, Georgia, Louisiana, Texas, New Mexico, Arizona and California in the Spanish Colonial period.

name: Modern Latin American History
description: $Introduces students to the socioeconomic, political, cultural, and environmental conditions that have shaped life in Latin America from the 1800s to the present. $Introduces students to the socioeconomic, political, cultural, and environmental conditions that have shaped life in Latin America from the 1800s to the present.

name: Traditional Asia and Its Legacy
description: $Civilizations of East Asia up to 1850, emphasizing traditional cultures in China and Japan, including religion, science, formation of empires, social life, and commerce. $Civilizations of East Asia up to 1850, emphasizing traditional cultures in China and Japan, including religion, science, formation of empires, social life, and commerce.

name: Asia in the Modern World
description: $Civilizations of India, China, and Japan since 1600, emphasizing Western impact and adaptation of these countries' political, economic, and social systems. $Civilizations of India, China, and Japan since 1600, emphasizing Western impact and adaptation of these countries' political, economic, and social systems.

name: Introduction to the History of Disease and Medicine
description: $Introduction to the history of disease and medicine since the Renaissance focusing on infectious diseases, the rise of germ theory, and evolution of medical training.  Cerdit not allowed for both HTS 2080 and HTS 3087. $Introduction to the history of disease and medicine since the Renaissance focusing on infectious diseases, the rise of germ theory, and evolution of medical training.  Cerdit not allowed for both HTS 2080 and HTS 3087.

name: The Scientific Revolution
description: $A critical approach to the Scientific Revolution, introducing students to primary documents and images from the period and emphasizing interpretive strategies and methods. $A critical approach to the Scientific Revolution, introducing students to primary documents and images from the period and emphasizing interpretive strategies and methods.

name: Technology and Science in the Industrial Age
description: $Surveys major developments in technology and science since 1600 and places them in the broader social context of their times. $Surveys major developments in technology and science since 1600 and places them in the broader social context of their times.

name: Technology and Society
description: $Analyzes social conditions that promote or retard technological activity, emphasizing role of business, the state, and scientific and engineering professions, and the emergence of consumerism. $Analyzes social conditions that promote or retard technological activity, emphasizing role of business, the state, and scientific and engineering professions, and the emergence of consumerism.

name: Reel History I: US History through Hollywood Films
description: $Students evaluate films as sources for specific historical events by viewing films, reading historical documents, and applying critical analysis to written assignments and class discussions. $Students evaluate films as sources for specific historical events by viewing films, reading historical documents, and applying critical analysis to written assignments and class discussions.

description: $Explores how urban neighborhoods work focusing on Westside neighborhoods from a variety of perspectives. Students will work with residents in designing a sustainability project.

name: Sci, Tech & Modern World
description: $An introduction to perspectives on how developments in science and technology at once reflect and influence politics and society on a global scale. $An introduction to perspectives on how developments in science and technology at once reflect and influence politics and society on a global scale.

description: $Interdisciplinary survey based on critical readings of the methods historians and social scientists use to generate knowledge about social life.  Students engage in "hands-on" research. $Interdisciplinary survey based on critical readings of the methods historians and social scientists use to generate knowledge about social life.
